UX Design Challenge: Tackling Sustainability in the E-Commerce Industry

Recycling and sustainability came in many forms, whether it is efficiency improvement, using renewable energy, materials reductions, or other carbon emission elimination tactics

Case summary

My mission to this design challenge is to design checkout screens for e-commerce app to help people recycle the goods they buy.

Problem Space

As the electronics evolve, it has changed the way we live and communicate. This revolution has also brought people around the world closer. Worldwide, we generate about 40 million tons of electronic waste every year, and that is like throwing away 800 laptops every second. However, we could change this. Recycling and sustainability came in many forms, whether it is efficiency improvement, using renewable energy, materials reductions, or other carbon emission elimination tactics. I focused on materials reduction, i.e.waste reduction, for the e-commerce industry to tackle sustainability.

User Research

To closely look at how different stakeholders tackle sustainability and recycling in the system, I identified their motivations and concerns via online archival research, user interviews, and surveys. Our target users are the customers of e-commerce. The stakeholders include the e-commerce company, recycling facilities, delivery businesses, and advocacy groups of climate change.

3 potential motivations of stakeholders:

  1. Those businesses which hope to achieve green policy may want to protect the habitat of pollinators.
  2. The customers or advocacy group of climate change wish to buy reused products that are good for the environment.
  3. Governmental funds on sustainable materials may motivate e-commerce businesses to recycle.

4 potential concerns of stakeholders:

  1. It takes much more effort for technical development. The recycling system is complicated and making new products out of recycling could be expensive. Therefore, small businesses and startup companies may not be able to afford the costs.
  2. The e-commerce business that does not have existing proper training in recycling might be against green cleaning policy
  3. The material production line could destroy natural habitat.
  4. It breaks the fast fashion trends by increasing costs and slowing down production time.

After analyzing the motivations and concerns of stakeholders. I look more closely at how e-commerce companies operate by inspecting the business models of the most popular shopping websites in North America and Asia: Amazon and Alibaba.

Alibaba

It operates as a middleman between buyers and sellers, and the company is divided into three core businesses:

  1. Alibaba charges merchants fees to appear higher on its search rankings.
  2. The sellers on Taobao, also known as a fee-free marketplace similar to eBay, will pay to rank higher on the site’s internal search engine. It generates advertising revenue for Alibaba.
  3. Tmall is an e-commerce site that caters to well-known brands, such as Nike and Apple. Alibaba then earns from its deposits, annual user fees, and sales commissions charged to retailers utilizing the site.

Amazon

A massive retailer for both new and used goods. Amazon sells products directly while also serving as an intermediary for other sellers. It takes a cut of the sale. Since it is a subscription-based business model through its Amazon Prime service, the users will pay an annual fee for benefits such as access to streaming media, and free-shipping. The company also offers mobile application purchases.

User Research Insights

For the first few days of our design challenge, we interviewed some customers and workers from different e-commerce companies. Through our stakeholder interview, we found out that some popular e-commerce businesses such as Amazon, Walmart, and other Chinese e-commerce businesses all have their own recycling programs that provide cashback or gift cards when customers return old or broken Amazon devices. However, not all customers are aware that the website provides recycling services. In addition, from one of our user interviews, one of the interviewees speaking from the customer’s perspective said,

“Recycling takes effort, but sometimes I got lazy.”

Though the customers are aware of the recycling service, the service might take too much effort that customers decline their incentives to utilize those services.

A question came to my mind:

How might we acknowledge the existence of the current recycling programs and encourage users to utilize them?

User Interview Insights Affinity diagrams on Miro

Existing App/Services

While I were generating ideas for the solution, I researched a couple of existing apps, websites, and services that could be helpful. I found six apps or websites that provide recycling services only, including ExtraCarbon, ECS e-waste app, Karma Recycling, Attero Recycling Zolopik Recycling, and nTrashJunk. Other recycling programs are featured under huge e-commerce businesses, such as Apple, Amazon, Walmart, and Alibaba. Common recycling program services include:

  • Users first send a picture of the item to an individual recycling agency, get a quote, place a pickup request or drop-off the item themselves, then receive vouchers, cashback, or store credit
  • Return the item or packaging to the original company then get cashback or store credits
  • Donate or resell by users themselves to a second-hand store

Ideation

Considering the existing apps and services, I came up with ideas that could potentially be featured on our prototype. The following ideas will focus on app design since they are more aligned with our design challenge problem.

  1. Redesign existing app — since a whole lot of huge e-commerce websites/apps already have their own recycling programs, such as Apple, Amazon, Walmart,etc., we considered to either modify the current recycling program or make the service more visible on the app
  2. Create a new app to track locations that need recycling services — this will be a new service that is only created to track wherever the recycling services are. There could be a courier to pick-up the recycling items or users drop-off at selected locations
  3. Add map features to the existing app which already has a recycling program — this feature allows the app to locate the locations to drop-off recycling items and different recycling items shows different locations, e.g. enter clothing to show second-hand store, enter packaging to show UPS, FedEx

Solutions and Design Features

Overall, customers in our user research expressed a positive attitude towards recycling services. The problem is, how do we acknowledge the existence of recycling services, furthermore, and encourage users to utilize the recycling services. As our user survey revealed that the majority of our participants chose Amazon as their favorite shopping site, we came up with a solution of Amazon app checkout screen redesign. The goal of our solution is to make more customers realize the existing recycling program as well as making the recycling process more convenient so more customers are willing to recycle.

My redesign mainly focused on two add-on features:

  1. Make the link to the recycling program (Amazon Second Chance) more visible on the Amazon app landing page by adding the link on top of the navigation bar and name it “Earn gift card” to increase incentives to click on. By doing so, it presented how customers could benefit from the recycling program as well as the existence of the program.

Created by Figma

  1. Have an optional question at the shopper’s checkout screen. The customer can choose if they have any current goods or electronics they wish to recycle. If they do, the next time when their delivery/package arrives, the courier/postman will pick up the things they want to recycle. By doing so, customers receive store credit instead of cash, and the cash will return to Amazon eventually thus increase the revenue
  2. This feature benefits both the customer and the company. First, it cut the time for the customer to find or get to a location, this aligned with our user research finding that 55% of the participants think timeliness of delivery time is very important or important. Since the delivery location and recycle pick-up location is the same, the carrier only needs to be there once (cut the time on transportation). Lastly, the company does not need to find a new or different carrier to only pick up the recycle items thus reduce the cost of delivery
  3. At the shopper’s checkout screen, there could be 2 options to deliver items wanted to return; first, the courier came to pick up the returned item when delivery at door, second is to drop-off the item, whether it is packaging or devices, at a designated store like UPS, FedEx store

Created by Figma

Usability Test Insights

To improve our prototype, we ran usability tests to get insight from potential users and explore the future direction of our design intervention. My prototype is the modified version after the usability tests, and the integrated feedback is listed below:

I have resolved the redundancy of the view location button by removing it on the checkout popup page, moved the “Earn gift card” feature to the most left on the top nav bar, and changed the “yes” “no” button on the checkout page to green and added the recycling question as “(optional)” to differentiate the priority between “place order”.

Main Takeaway

As I went through our design process, we figured that there are some features that Amazon Second Chance offered but we didn’t focus on, which are donate, resell, repair features. We hope we could develop those on our add-on features on the checkout screen as well as develop the same checkout screen with add-on features on the website.

Furthermore, we hope that the concept of making existing recycling programs more visible could be expanded on more e-commerce websites and apps. In that case, users acknowledge the importance of recycling and make it a new shopping habit.
